<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_shutdown:
```c
void metal_linux_irq_shutdown(void)
{
	int ret;

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "%s\n", __func__);
	irq_handling_stop = true;
	metal_linux_irq_notify();
	ret = pthread_join(irq_pthread, NULL);
	if (ret) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed to join IRQ thread: %d.\n",
			  ret);
	}
	close(irq_notify_fd);
	metal_mutex_deinit(&irq_lock);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_linux_irq_shutdown:
static int metal_linux_irq_notify(void)
{
	uint64_t val = 1;
	int ret;

	ret = write(irq_notify_fd, &val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s failed\n", __func__);
	}
	return ret;
}
...
static void metal_linux_irq_set_enable(struct metal_irq_controller *irq_cntr,
				       int irq, unsigned int state)
{
	int offset, ret;

	if (irq < irq_cntr->irq_base ||
	    irq >= irq_cntr->irq_base + irq_cntr->irq_num) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s: invalid irq %d\n",
			  __func__, irq);
		return;
	}
	offset = irq - linux_irq_cntr.irq_base;
	metal_mutex_acquire(&irq_lock);
	if (state == METAL_IRQ_ENABLE)
		metal_bitmap_set_bit(irqs_enabled, offset);
	else
		metal_bitmap_clear_bit(irqs_enabled, offset);
	metal_mutex_release(&irq_lock);
	/* Notify IRQ thread that IRQ state has changed */
	ret = metal_linux_irq_notify();
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR,
			  "%s: failed to notify set %d enable\n",
			  __func__, irq);
	}
}

{

	/* Shutdown IRQ handling */
	metal_linux_irq_shutdown();
	metal_linux_bus_finish();
	close(_metal.pagemap_fd);

}

void metal_linux_bus_finish(void)
{
	struct linux_bus *lbus;
	struct metal_bus *bus;

	for_each_linux_bus(lbus) {
		if (metal_bus_find(lbus->bus_name, &bus) == 0)
			metal_bus_unregister(bus);
	}
}
...
void metal_finish(void)
{
	if (--_metal.common.ref_count != 0)
		return;

	metal_sys_finish();
	memset(&_metal, 0, sizeof(_metal));
}

```c
void metal_linux_irq_shutdown(void)
{
	int ret;

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "%s\n", __func__);
	irq_handling_stop = true;
	metal_linux_irq_notify();
	ret = pthread_join(irq_pthread, NULL);
	if (ret) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed to join IRQ thread: %d.\n",
```

Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: metal_linux_irq_shutdown calls metal_linux_irq_notify, pthread_join, close and metal_mutex_deinit. metal_linux_irq_notify (shown) performs a write and does not call metal_linux_irq_shutdown (nor any function that calls it), so there is no direct or indirect recursion. (A specific violation scenario would be if metal_linux_irq_notify — or any function it calls — called metal_linux_irq_shutdown, e.g. metal_linux_irq_notify -> some_func -> metal_linux_irq_shutdown, creating an indirect recursion.)
